title: Champion Mastery is a Sham
body:
When the Champion Mastery system first came out, I was kind of intrigued.  It was a way to show skill with a particular champion.  However, it's implementation is flawed, and points essentially amount to whether you win or lose, not how you perform.  The strangest part is that the system actually does seem to know when you're performing well, even in a loss.  I've seen grade S to A in a loss, so something under the hood is working (one would think).

But it doesn't seem to have any bearing on how many champion points you are awarded at the end of a match.  Most recently, I finished a game as Elise going 6/2/0 (our Caitlyn was constantly DCing, so we surrendered at 20:23).  At the time, I had the most gold on our team, 3rd most gold in the game, and was responsible for 6 of 10 kills we amassed.  I finished the game with an A+ grade, which I think that was reasonable.  And out of curiosity, I hovered over the number of champion points I was awarded...

I got +37 for that game.  A+ rank, only +37 points.  Compare this to a game where I went 0/8/4 as Riven feeding my ass off.  That game we still won, and I got over 1000 pts for a C performance.  (By the way, If that was a C, what do you have to do to get a D?)

In the end, the only thing Champion Mastery tracks is how often you win the game with a particular champion, which I find shortsighted and foolish.

replies.body: Agree... points should be based on performance (because obviously the are good at measuring it) and not on win/loss

I have to disagree. If you separate champion mastery from winning the game, then you are going to get people who don't care about winning the game as long as they get champion mastery points. So they'll just run off and farm or try to get solo kills rather than teamfighting, taking objectives and actually winning the game (because those things wouldn't grant you mastery points).

Though, that would only be a problem if you could still get a lot of mastery points for losing a game. Maybe it would make sense if you always got very few mastery points for a lost game, but would only get a lot of points for a won game if you performed well.

Well, a solution to promote playing well is to have quantified scores, such as Minion Kills, Time spent alive, Objectives taken, and Damage Dealt.  This will at least promote players to perform well, even if they do not win.  Champion Mastery shouldn't be about winning with that champion; it should be an indicator on how well someone plays X champion.

To play devil's advocate for a moment, in the end, it IS winning that matters. It doesn't matter if you go 20/0/15. It doesn't matter if you single handedly got 5 dragons and 2 barons. It doesn't matter if you healed more than the entire enemy team did damage. All of that is for naught if you can't win the game. In the end, victory is what you are after. Winning is the single best way to prove that you know a character. As one of my favorite quotes goes "It's not those who are strong who win. It's those who win who are strong."

False. Winning is the single best way to prove that your team was better than theirs. Your actual accomplishments during that game are irrelevant according to Champion Mastery. Regardless of how you actually did, you're awarded thousands of points, even if all you did was stand there.

I'd actually be interested to see that Champion Mastery report. If I just stand around the base but my team wins anyways, how many points would I get according to Champion Mastery? I did no damage, farmed no gold beyond the ambient gains, and contributed in no way to any meaninful statistic. I'd bet it's still more points than an S ranked player on the losing team. And that's messed up.
You'd be hit with the afk buster long before that. If you don't earn XP or gold for a while, it counts you as gone.

I unfortunately have first hand knowledge of that due to some weird delay that prevented me from moving among other things. I got 1500 points for a 60 minute game we managed to win while going 0/1/0 (i was breifly able to move and wound up dying to the least fed enemy). I dont know what grade i got because i was stuck in game long after it ended and couldn't access the post-game lobby

The problem being, that winning is SO much more important than grade. Personally, were I to design it, I'd make grade C the break point. Anyone on the losing side with grade B and above would receive more point than anyone on the losing side with grade C and below. Learning how to properly fight a losing match is vastly more important than learning how to not throw a winning one. 

You're right, winning is the most important part here, but it shouldn't overshadow grade by over 300% (according to OP given stats).

When it comes to Champ Mastery,
The points are meaningless.Their just there to speed up or slow down your "mastering".
The tiers are just a way to show off.That's all it's there for.
The end game grades is the important & only useful thing here.The grades allow you to gauge you performance on a champ & where you stand in terms of mastery.If you,on average,get "S"s & "A"s,you can say you pretty much mastered the champ.If you get "C"s & "D"s,then you need to work on several things (to bad the players can't tell what are factored into these grades).

I've always thought that as your rank gets higher a win or a loss should matter less. An S+ loss should be worth ~80% of an S+ win with something around a B being the point where the system acts like it does now.
It's more of a grind system than anything else; I'd rather they just give flat points for win/loss and tie in the grades to another system.

i agree dude. some can get a d- and get 1200 points while you get a s+ and get 200 points. the system if very misleading. it makes people who performed bad think they still did well even tho they got carried while the guy that broke his back trying to carry his team will be stuck thinking "if only i had a better team".

Champion Mastery is not a sham. Show me one official statement that claims this is a skillbased system? Its not! It never has been, and just because you think it is, dosent make it a sham.
Champion Mastery does only show to a ceratint extend how much you have played a certain champ. Yes, you get a grade at the end of each game, showing how you did in that game, but those two systems are completley individual.

Champion Mastery points are base more on time used than anything else, and since its a system where you cant loose points, its outright idiotic to think this has soemthing to do with skill. 

Now, that said, why would you care of the rank of a players champ?
1: We assume that people normally play to win.
2: We assume that most of the playerbase have normal cognitive abilities.

If our assumptions are correct, a player that has spent more time with a champ, will perform better with this champ, because they have experience in playing him. It wont say anything about the persons general LoL skill, it will only tell you he has picked a champion he knows, and that he is more likley to play at the upper level of **his own **skill tree. Whever in the division system that might be!

The funny thing is, Riot should already know about this. If they check the general situation on the boards when Champ Masteries were released (which they should when they release new content) they would have seen similar complaints.

Riot attempted to take Champion Mastery from Heroes of the Storm (Which has you level your hero and as you gain you unlock things -- such as**_ base model recolors_**)  Which gives sizable experience even on a loss, much more than the ratio for League

They then removed all the rewards that the HotS model has (Gold, skin customization, etc) and said "well shit, we don't want something that requires EFFORT to introduce" so they put titles which at no time show, and a single universal emote.

They then arbitrarily put a game by game "rating" that can be inflated by simply winning the game hard and fast and doesn't reflect who your opponents are.

IMO, there should be two things:

1. **Experience** - how much you played with a champion working pretty much as is now.
2. **Skill** - using only performance part of current system and working as an arithmetic average. e.g. how you currently calculate average champion KDA.
